text: So, welcome everybody to session two of the UVM Extension New Farmer Project's Groundwork Program, Linking Mechanization to Farm Business Planning. Our presenters today are John Hendrickson and also Jennifer Phillips. Both John and Jennifer can tell you a little bit about themselves. I think they prefer to do a self-introduction. But for now, I'll just mention that John is joining us from the University of Wisconsin and Jennifer from New York's Hudson Valley. So welcome to both of you and I will pass it over to John. Hello everyone. We're getting up to 36 degrees out here in Wisconsin today, which is just really exciting, given the polar vortex conditions that we've had. Thanks, Kristen, and it's a pleasure to talk to everyone today. It's interesting. I do a lot of speaking to groups and maybe it's just because I don't do webinars as much, but I'm more nervous and anxious today than I am when I'm in front of a big group of people and they're staring at me. But I'm sure we'll get things going smoothly here. So my name is John Hendrickson and as Kristen said, I work at the University of Wisconsin specifically. I'm an educator and researcher at the Center for Integrated Agricultural Systems. We are a sustainable agriculture research and education unit. And actually we're celebrating our 25th anniversary this year. And so that's really exciting. I've been with the Center for actually most of those 25 years. I'm getting to be an old fart around here. My appointment at the University is a nine month academic year appointment, 75% time, which leaves me a very small sliver of my life to try to run my own farm. And so I'm an organic vegetable grower at Stone Circle Farm, which is about 30 miles away from Madison, quite small scale because I can't do too much in the amount of time that I have away from my university work. We grow a lot of garlic, a lot of carrots and a lot of hot peppers and are moving into doing year round sales through the winter time with some of our root crops. And we sell mostly to restaurants. And so that's just a little tiny bit about my farm. I'd love to talk more about my farm but I don't get to do that today. In terms of my university work, I do a lot of beginning grower training programs. These feature two to three day intensive workshops. We have one on vegetable production, our market growers workshop. And actually a weekend after next we have a cut flower workshop that we run basically every other year. And then I also coordinate a school for beginning apple growers as well. And we're thinking about doing more schools moving forward because these are incredibly popular and there's an incredible amount of demand for them. Just quickly here I've got a sketch of some of the types of work that I engage in. I do a lot of work on economics and record keeping and labor issues on farms and marketing. And I've got scale in bold there because for me the scale issue is just really critical to just about any topic related to the farming. I'm going to pause there and allow Jennifer to introduce herself. Thanks John. I'll be brief here. So thanks for inviting me today. I have been raising sheep and beef cattle here in the Hudson Valley for about ten years. The scale of my farm is moderately small. I raise about 50 years, sell about 100 lambs a year and I sold my beef herd last year. And I also have the academic hat on like John. I teach at the Center for Environmental Policy at Bard College. We run a graduate program, master's program and environmental policy there. And my focus at the center is on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change interactions with agriculture. So my contribution here today will just be to add a little bit now and then with some perspective on the livestock angle. So thanks John. Go right ahead. Great. Thanks Jennifer. We invited Jennifer to join me today because my work really focuses almost exclusively on vegetable production. And while some of the information and ideas that I'm going to be sharing today are generalizable, I wanted to ensure that we had some perspectives and examples from the livestock side as well. Just before I leave this slide, I'll just quickly mention this grower to grower report. That's the picture there on this slide. This is a report I did a number of years ago looking at economics at different scales of production on vegetable farms and really kind of forms the foundation for a lot of the work that I've done since we published that back in 2005. If you're interested in that report, it's a free download from the Center for Integrated Ag Systems website. Okay, so scale. I really think that this quote kind of sums it up for me and this is a quote from the market farming listserv that I subscribe to. And this is not a quote from me, but I think the whole thing comes down to this. What is the right scale for my operation? The challenge is to find a size that represents a good fit for a grower's management skills. And of course, there's a whole set of issues that are wrapped up in that scale issue. How much land you have available to you, what your quality of life goals are, what your income needs are, and maybe just as big a factor as the scale of your operation is your crop and market diversity. This is especially true on diversified vegetable farms where the level of diversity can be quite high and also the amount of marketing, and the different types of marketing engaged in can be quite high as well. And then that all, the big issues that that settles down to is how are you going to manage labor and what types of tools and equipment are you going to use on your farm? This is a rundown of the goals for today's session. I know that you all received this set of goals, so I'm not going to go over these one by one. You all received these as a prelude to today's session. This is my goal for today is to run through most of these, or all of these in some level of detail. Before we get started, I want to kind of put mechanization in context. And a lot of this context, again, is going to be based on my experience as a vegetable grower and working with vegetable growers. Especially in the early years of a farm's development, mechanization is most often linked to expansion. So a farm starts out real small, maybe with not a whole lot of tools and equipment. And then as they get bigger, they find the need to acquire those tools and equipment in order to get the work accomplished in a reasonable fashion. So that expansion can be an acreage, it can be a herd size. It can also be in terms of the different markets and enterprises that a farm may engage in as they move forward with their farm operation. At the same time, as we're trying to mechanize, we often have very little capitalization funds to do that. And there are a lot of growers who are quite adverse to debt and risk. And so that limits their available capitalization funds even more because many people don't like to rush out to the bank and put themselves in that debt situation. But that situation that most growers do find themselves in, unless they've inherited land or find themselves in an incubator situation or what have you, is land cost. And this can really limit the amount of money that a grower has available to mechanize. And so what that usually does is puts them on kind of a long, slow process of mechanization over time. There are very few growers that can kind of run out and buy that equipment package that they dream about all at once. Oh, if we could do that. This is really obvious, but mechanization is very closely linked to labor. This is especially true on a diversified vegetable farm where there's just a lot of hand work. And a lot of that hand work takes a lot of time. And so payroll becomes a real significant issue. And in some regards, mechanization is an attempt to try to hone in that labor cost or at least make it more effective and more productive. And to recognize that mechanization purchases are not just about getting some work done, but they're really investments in your business. And they have a significant impact on a business's financial picture in terms of your net worth and your annual budget picture, financial picture for your farm. Another reality is that it is quite common for investments, decisions to be made with very little financial analysis, and this can certainly lead to problems. On real large scale farms, it can lead pretty quickly to real significant debt and really nasty situations between your banker. But a lot of small farms can kind of keep us at bay because generally the equipment needed is not generally as expensive as a large scale grain farm. I know a lot of farms that just kind of jump in and get started without a business plan. I'm a firm believer that at least a simple basic business plan is a really important step to take. And an important section in a business plan should be your start-up expenses and capitalization. So what tools are you going to need to run this business? What are those going to cost? And how are you going to pay for those? In order to estimate your needs and expenses accurately, I think it's really, really important to visit other farms, attend conferences and trade shows. And of course these days so much information is available online and so you have the ubiquitous command to just Google it and find out. It is actually a great research tool, the Internet. In addition to figuring out deciding what kinds of equipment and tools you need, you need to figure out how you're going to pay for those. Savings, family contributions, where they're going to go get a loan. And in many cases what's involved is reinvestment. Those first few years, if you're able to make some money, you're usually plowing that money right back into the farm in terms of capitalizing and mechanizing. So this is something that I recommend that all farms start with. This is basically an example of what you might include in your business plan in terms of that start-up expenses and capitalization. You list the items that you're going to need. I think it's nice to have two columns in terms of cost. What's it going to cost new, you know, top of the line or maybe a lower cost alternative or used. And then also to include a cost to rent or hire, which is an option, especially as you get started. And then you might have a column out to decide to make some notes or to give different types of tools and equipment a priority ranking as you move forward. One thing that I think is really helpful is to set up categories, which can help you plan more accurately and systematically. So for your farm, you can set up categories of things, categories of tools and equipment that you're going to need so you can make sure that you're covering all your bases. For a vegetable farm, this might be a power source, you know, your tractor or if you're farming with horses, it could be horses. The tools that are going to be attached to that power source, and then you can break those down into different types of tools, tillage, cultivation, harvest, et cetera. And then it's really important to consider the post-harvest and delivery aspects as well on a vegetable farm. And those categories are going to be different based on the type of farm, the farm that you're going to have for a livestock farm. You might have different categories. Obviously manure handling, you might be doing that on your vegetable farm, but for an animal farm, you're definitely going to be doing that. And then you're going to be looking to make hay and transporting animals around so that the categories might be different. So just a quick check-in to make sure that you all are paying attention and following along. This is one of these multiple choice questions that we are going to ask you to weigh in on and ask you, what do you think it costs on a per acre basis to capitalize a vegetable farm in terms of equipment? And, Kristyn, if you want to jump in here and you probably can tell people how to choose multiple choice questions faster than I do. Sure. So what I'm going to do is actually make the polls, the polling type. How many choices do we need, John? Four? Five. All right. So thank you for your patience. So now you can go up to the polling box to the right of the smiley face icon and choose your answer, A, B, C, D, or E. And we'll give folks about a minute and then I'll hit publish poll and then we'll all be able to see what the answers were. And John, I'm not sure if you see Kristyn's question where she says, wouldn't five be different per acre than 15 with the average cost per acre decreasing? As you're answering that, I'll hit publish poll. Sure. Sure. Yeah, this is a general question and things can certainly vary on a per acre basis. I've actually collected information on this. Some of it is contained in that Grower to Grower report that I found. And I actually found, well, there's certainly a great deal of variation from scale to scale of farm that you look at a collection of farms and you look at enough farms and you actually find that it actually can be relatively even across farms of different scales. So we've got some people that didn't vote, but we have people coming in actually pretty evenly distributed across B, C, and D. And I'm going to go to my next slide here and based on the information that I've gathered from farms, I've seen things in the range from $10,000 to $20,000 per acre. And so I kind of use that as a general rule of thumb in terms of capitalization. And one thing to say here is it certainly is going to vary whether we're talking about the initial price of the equipment or after you've got that on your farm, what the resale value is going to be for that equipment. And also, obviously, it's going to be impacted by whether we're going to include facilities. For this exercise, I chose to exclude facilities. But I really have seen that even for small farms, two, three acres, this can be the case where growers are investing $10,000 to $20,000 per acre in order to grow vegetables. I'm going to ask Jennifer to chime in here in terms of livestock here in a second. But before we leave this slide, just to give you a snapshot of things that we might be looking at in terms of capitalizing a fresh market vegetable farm, we're going to need a set of facilities. We're likely going to need a greenhouse to grow transplants, perhaps as a place to grow crops as well in terms of hoop house production. You're going to need a place to wash and pack. And you're going to need a cooler. And then in terms of equipment, this is just a real brief sketch of some things that might be an initial priority equipment list for a vegetable farm. There's a question here in terms of whether that's $10,000 to $20,000 invested annually. Now, this is your equipment package that you have on your farm spread over your acreage and vegetables. If anybody has a question that I miss in the chat box, please alert me to that because I'm not looking at the chat box vigorously here. Jennifer, do you want to chime in here and switch to the next slide here? And have you weigh in on what it might cost to capitalize a livestock operation? Sure. It's a little bit different. I think it depends so much on how many animals you're starting with because there's a lot you can get away with when you've only got a few animals to begin. The two main things that I found I had to have under my own control were ability to brush hog my pastures because in most cases you're starting out with pastures that aren't in the kind of condition you need them to be in, especially if you're grass-fed, you need pretty high quality pasture. And once you have a whole lot of animals to begin with, and you can do some serious mob grazing where you're really concentrating animals, you really need to mow a lot in order to get your quality up. So I think you need some kind of a tractor to begin with. And then the other part of the season that you need to think about with a tractor is that unless you've got less than, say, 15 sheep or a couple of cows, you really need to be using round bales for winter feed as opposed to small square bales. And so you need to be able to move them. And so you have to have a tractor for that. I know of a few small-scale sheep farmers around here that tried to start their operation without a tractor, and it didn't work for who-how. But most, you listed a set of issues that a livestock farmer may face right in the beginning, and that's handling manure, haymaking, and transport. And I think it will depend a lot on your situation whether or not you might be able to be feeding, doing winter feeding on pasture so you really don't have a lot of manure handling to deal with. I actually-I use a winter area, but my vegetable farmer neighbor across the road, he transports all my manure and spreads some of it for me and spreads the rest on his own fields every year. So I don't need any manure handling equipment. And haymaking, I think, until you get to a pretty sizable operation, in my perspective, it does not make sense to make your own hay and have hay making equipment. I purchased hay for the first nine years of my operation, and this past year was the first year I had hay made by somebody custom on my farm. And the advantage there is, of course, you don't have to deal with the labor of it. And the hay that I was purchasing was better quality than I was able to have made on this farm because when you're hiring custom operators, of course, you're competing with everybody else they're trying to make hay for, so you don't necessarily get it done when you want. But purchasing hay, that hay had been stored indoors from a large-scale hay producer. So it's-and he was delivering-you know, he would deliver to me once a week so I could store it inside my barn when he delivered round bales. So it's much better quality than what I could have done on my own farm. It costs more, but it's also a lot of labor that I don't have to put out if I'm purchasing all my hay or having somebody make it custom on my farm. And then transport, one of the big advantages of-I don't have a truck, I don't have a stock trailer, and it's been a little bit of a challenge finding livestock haulers when I need them. But one of the advantages there because of running this farm by myself and not having anybody else to help is if somebody else is there with a truck, they're also helping load animals. So if I had to do that by myself, I would need to hire somebody to come and help me load each time. So there's definitely advantages to hiring custom. And I think at my scale, you know, I'm sending animals every couple of weeks, maybe 20 lambs at a time. It's-it wouldn't pay for me to own and pay taxes and insurance on a livestock trailer. So I think there's definitely-you've made the point about scale being important. It's really critical that you think about how much you're really going to use that equipment, or if you can get somebody else to do it, there's a big advantage there. Thanks, Jennifer. I also did want to note that Erica sent in a question. I'm not sure if you and John saw it, where she says fencing and water infrastructure should be included in the start-up capitalization too, right? Do you have anything to say to that? Well, I'll just note. I mean, I think from my perspective, since we're focusing on mechanization and tractors, I wasn't thinking too much about that. I-I'll make one comment about fencing. Almost all of the fencing on my farm is portable electric and polywire. So I don't have very much permanent fencing at all. Permanent fencing is super expensive. And especially when you're just starting up, you may not necessarily know exactly where you want those fences. So I think a fencing is something that over many, many years, I might slowly start to put some permanent fences on this farm. But in water, I use all the orchard tubing above ground. Pretty inexpensive. I've got water in every paddock, but it was really inexpensive to put it in. So that was not a big cost for me. My tractor cost me a lot more than anything else cost me to get started. And I appreciate having it. I couldn't run this farm without a tractor. Thanks, Jennifer. I, too, I did not neglect thinking about fencing in water. I was actually thinking about putting those in the categories on that cost chart that I put up. But like Jennifer said, I chose not to do that given that the emphasis of this webinar was on tractors and mechanization, as opposed to some of those other infrastructure costs. But clearly, clearly, if we're working with growers and particularly beginning growers, we need to be clear about the complete capitalization cost. So point well taken. So thank you. So a bit more about this mechanization planning. When you're setting up that chart, I said you should set up categories to make sure that you're covering all your bases. Chances are you're probably not going to ever cover all your bases. There's always going to be something that you didn't anticipate. So it's very smart to include a contingency's line item in your business plan to account for the things that you just didn't think of. You can get an idea from experienced growers, kind of what they think a good contingency budget might be. As a general rule, I've heard that totaling up all of the things that you did think of and taking 20% of that is, as a decent way to account for contingency's in terms of startup capitalization expenses on a farm. And then the other thing, and maybe this is my own ignorance showing through, but when I started my farm, I didn't grow up on a farm. I came to farming from suburbia. I had this notion when I started my farm that once I got this tractor and this piece of equipment and that piece of equipment, and I got my washing and packing shed set up that I was going to be done. And then I was just going to be smooth sailing after that. And that Grower to Crow report that I did, which include farms that had been farming for 20, 30 or more years, I realized that a farm has never done capitalizing, that there's always a new tool, there's a tractor breakdown, there's a new roof that needs to be put on, et cetera. You're never done. And then lastly, if you're dealing with growers or if you're a grower yourself and you haven't done that business plan, it's never too late. It's never too late to sit down and write up a plan. In some ways it's easier after you get started because you know more than you did before you started. So it's really important to do a fair amount of research. This is a research project when you do a business plan. I've already said this, but I think the most important thing that growers can do, whether they're beginning or not, is to visit other farms. And I really like to ask lots and lots of questions when I visit a farm. Try to find out how many acres are in production or the herd or flock size, how many different crops they're growing, how they're marketing. Try to get a list of all their equipment and how much those things cost. Look around at the buildings, how are they used, what's the square footage, how many workers, how many hours are being hired on the farm. And then what you can do with that level of data is to use that in terms of planning and projections. And what I like to do is think in terms of ratios. So what is the herd size per acre? How much square feet of greenhouse space does this farm have per acre of vegetables in production? How many people are they hiring per acre? Those kinds of things can really help with planning. So in terms of scaling up, which is often associated with mechanization, again, some of these slides are based on the fact that I work with a lot of beginning growers and do a lot of beginning grower trainings. One thing that I really emphasize is that you can never be too small as a beginning farmer, but it's pretty easy to be too big. And I also believe that slow, steady growth is generally less painful than rapid growth. And I've seen a tendency, certainly, among vegetable growers for unplanned growth. And what often happens on a vegetable farm is that when you're sitting in your greenhouse in March, it's really easy to, oh, I think I'll plant another flat of these tomatoes. It's really easy to plant another flat or push that earthly cedar another 100 feet or 200 feet. That part is easy. What comes afterwards, if you weren't planning for that expansion, is not so easy. And some of the most sage advice that I ever heard in terms of expansion on a vegetable farm is that you should only expand, and this is especially true for organic vegetables, obviously, only expand as your capacity to stay on top of weeds allows. And if we don't follow that rule, you unfortunately end up with situations like this, where I think that's some broccoli in there amidst the can of the fissile and who knows what else is in there. The livestock equivalent, I guess, would be, you know, don't expand beyond the capacity of your pasture to handle that increased herd or flock size. So, you know, don't expand beyond the carrying capacity of the land that you have. So, when doing those critical growth steps as we expand, good to expand in reasonable steady steps, I personally believe that it's good to, when you're expanding an acreage, to not take on significant new complex enterprises at the same time. So, if you're deciding to go from four to eight acres in vegetables, it may not be the best time to also plant an apple orchard on your farm, or suddenly decide to, you know, raise 200 meat birds or something like that. Just try to keep your life a little sane by not expanding in more than one direction and more than one way at one time. And I like to follow the lead of my existing customers and markets rather than trying to do brand new things with expanded production. And as we expand, of course, it usually means more employees and more equipment. I think these are some of the keys, I think, to settling the scale issue. You know, settling the scale issue is different from grower to grower. You know, that initial quote that I put was, you're matching the scale of the farm to the management abilities and skills of the grower. The right scale for me may not be the right scale for my friend down the road. The key is to settling that issue. I'm a firm believer that we've got to do really good record keeping on farms in order to figure out what's working and what's not. Obviously, we've got to appropriately mechanize, and that's what we're going to be talking about here through the rest of the presentation. I think it's really important to settle on the markets that work best for you and a lot of beginning growers that in the beginning try to do a lot of different types of marketing. They start doing farmers markets and they add a CSA and they start selling to restaurants and to the co-op and maybe do some view pick and they're doing all kinds of different things. Most people find that over time they settle into some niches that work best for them and for their farm and for the markets, for the area that they're in. And then obviously we need to solve the labor puzzle. So just quickly on record keeping because I think it's so important. This is not necessarily a mechanization topic, but I think it's really key in order to be able to mechanize effectively. We've got to have good information in order to make decisions about mechanization. So we've got to track numbers on our farm. We've got to track sales for all our products and all our markets. I still run into people who sell at farmers markets and don't have any idea at the end of the year how much broccoli they sold versus tomatoes versus other things. And I'm just baffled by the fact that people aren't tracking their sales more accurately. On the other side we've got to track expenses, both production in terms of the marketing. And I think it's really important to track your labor and especially given that you're going to be using this information to make mechanization decisions and that's so tied into labor. I think it's really important to track labor on a farm and track labor by crop or by enterprise on your farm. And then we've got to use that data to evaluate crops and enterprises thoroughly and honestly. Just briefly we have developed a program called Veggie Compass here at the University of Wisconsin which is a tool for whole farm profit management. It's a series of spreadsheets which enable vegetable farms and certainly other types of farms could use it as well but it's mainly designed for a vegetable grower to track costs by crop and by market. So to track profitability by crop and by market. I'm going to spend a whole lot of time on Veggie Compass training as a whole day session in and of itself but I wanted to alert you to the fact that this exists. It's a series of Excel spreadsheets that are free download from VeggieCompass.com and I'd be happy to visit with folks if they want to email me afterwards and ask questions about Veggie Compass. So in terms of mechanizing for vegetables, it's certainly quite possible to get started with, and this is a quote from a grower that I know quite well. She says, I got started with a shovel of rake in a hoe and you know, at $300 in the bank. And while that's certainly possible, most growers will find over time that a whole range of tools and facilities are needed to grow and market effectively, profitably and sustainably. Particularly as you get older, that rake, shovel and hoe really start to become less appealing as you age and your knees and back start complaining. In terms of livestock, I think actually there's some kind of big initial differences and I certainly heard what Jennifer said in terms of not needing to necessarily invest in haymaking equipment from the get-go. But unlike vegetables, there are some things that you kind of just need to do on an animal farm that you're probably just not going to do by hand on an animal farm. So you can grow a lot of vegetables and generate a lot of gross income with very little tools and equipment in terms of vegetables. So you can do things by hand. You can transplant by hand. You can weed by hand. You can harvest by hand. You can wash by hand. You can do all these things by hand. When it comes to livestock, you got some changes, some differences here where if you got any amount of animals, you're probably not going to want to handle that manure by hand. You're going to want a skid loader and a manure spreader. And certainly in terms of the pasture that Jennifer mentioned, you're going to need a way to maintain your pastures. Even if your pastures are in really good shape down the row, down the line, you're going to need to mow the borders and things like that. So having a means to do that is just virtually necessary from the get-go. Whereas you can start growing vegetables without a tractor. And the other thing that's very true in terms of livestock is that you may find it easier and common to having an alternative to buying equipment. As Jennifer mentioned, she buys her hay in. She mentioned that it's more expensive. I actually am not so sure. My guess is it is probably far less expensive. It may seem expensive when she's paying that price for hay made for her. But in terms of owning the equipment and the labor cost of producing that hay yourself and having that equipment being idle for a good portion of the year, chances are more often than not that it's going to be far more economical to custom hire or buy that hay rather than make it yourself. So just some general mechanization advice. And this first one is probably more directed at myself. This is the problem that I combat on my own farm is being just wishy-washy and not being afraid to invest and kind of just spending endless hours analyzing things and shopping and comparing alternatives and getting stuck in this paralysis by analysis phase. It's going to cost money to run a farm. You're going to have to invest in your business and you've got to be ready to do that. I think it's actually important to go through a period where you don't rush out and do a lot of those purchases, especially for our beginning farmer that maybe didn't grow up on a farm to make sure that farming is going to be right for you. So I think it's necessarily a bad idea to have a little bit of wishy-washingness in the beginning and wait to make sure that this quality of life and the finances are likely to work out before you start investing in tools. And a lot of vegetable growers that I talk to report that equipment pays for itself quite quickly on a vegetable farm. This is especially true for intensive high-value production because you're able to generate quite a bit of income on a per acre basis. And so that cultivating tool or a transplanter can pay for itself quite quickly in terms of reducing labor costs and getting labor done more efficiently. And just a couple other points on here. I had to sell them on the bottom. If it doesn't work, sell it. I've visited a lot of vegetable farms where they've obviously acquired a lot of tools and equipment over time. And a lot of them are just kind of sitting around in the weeds and not, you know, kind of would definitely fall in the unproductive asset category if your banker came out and visited your farm. And some good advice I have a grower friend up in northern Wisconsin and he's really good about, you know, if something doesn't work for his farm or in his operation, he tries it for a little while. And if it doesn't work, he sells it. He doesn't hold on to it and have it sit there in the weeds. Another point there is that it can take multiple years to kind of fully integrate a new piece of equipment or machine on your farm. It takes a little while to tweak that cultivator and get it set up or to train yourself or your workers to use a tool to its maximum effectiveness. So that's something to keep in mind, whether you're a grower or whether you're advising growers, is that it can take time. You know, the tool doesn't necessarily just waltz into your farm and start working perfectly from day one. So in terms of setting goals, priorities and decisions, you know, it comes back to the goals for your business and setting those, writing those down. And this includes economic and quality of life goals for your farm. Again, I think it's really important to visit other farms and talk to other growers as you're setting goals and priorities and making decisions. And another really good piece of advice is that when you're considering buying a piece of equipment, is to get some references from the person that you're buying it from so you can talk to people that have used it and used it more than one season. It's a really, really good advice. And then there's a set of questions to ask, you know, do you really need to own it? Can you rent this piece of equipment, at least in the beginning? Maybe it's not a long-term solution, but maybe it's a solution temporarily. Or can you custom hire the work? Can you lease it with an option to buy? Or can you trade in barter for that piece of equipment? In order to accurately determine whether it makes sense to buy something rather than rent or custom hire, it's important to consider the true cost of ownership. And that's, you know, that's beyond just the purchase price. On an annual basis, you've got depreciation. You've got interest if you borrowed money to buy that piece of equipment. You may have major repairs. You're certainly going to have maintenance. You may have insurance if it's a building. It's going to cost labor to use that piece of equipment. Obviously, if it's a tractor, it's going to eat fuel and oil. And then for, especially for buildings, you may have taxes on that asset. So you should estimate all those total costs of ownership on an annual basis. And then you should divide those annual costs over an increment that makes sense in terms of the comparison. So say for a building, if you're going to put up a building and you need to compare the costs in terms of renting a building, that might be on a monthly basis. So you divide that annual cost by 12 and try to figure out whether it makes sense or not. In terms of a tractor, it might be an hourly basis but that's what your equipment dealer is going to charge you on an hourly basis to rent a tractor. In terms of field equipment, in terms of comparing with customer hire, it might be on a per acre basis. So the cost of owning that hay-making equipment versus the per acre cost that a custom operator is going to charge you to come in and harvest that hay for you. And you need to be honest about those costs. And then it's equally important to not just look at those numbers but really figure out whether it's practical and economical to do the rent or custom hire. Is, you know, can you even rent a waterwheel transplant or in your area if you're a vegetable grower? Probably not. And this is where there's a lot more options in terms of livestock production and green production in terms of being able to rent equipment. A lot of vegetable equipment is quite specialized and not available to rent. Some exceptions to that is you might be able to have a neighbor chisel plow for you. So more about goals, priorities, and decisions. So before you go out and buy, these are some questions that I think you should ask yourself or if you are an extension person working with growers, these are some questions that you could ask them or encourage them to ask themselves. Does it fit within the context of your farm plan? Does it fit your scale? And maybe even more importantly, does it fit the scale that you want to reach? What does it cost? What is it cost to operate? What is its resale value? And here's something that's actually quite on the advantage side in terms of vegetable production is that a lot of vegetable equipment doesn't lose its value very much because a lot of vegetable equipment is in high demand. A great example of that is the Alice Charmas Model G Tractor. If you find one of those and keep it in good condition, chances are you're probably going to be able to sell it for more than you bought it for. Is it durable? Can you repair it yourself? Is it easy to use? Is it enjoyable to use? Can other people on your farm use it? I've got a tractor on my farm that I'm basically the only person that can push the clutch in all the way because it's an old tractor and my five-foot wife and my less-than-full-grown sons can't push the clutch in all the way. So they can't operate that tractor. Is it sustainable if that's important for you? And I think it should be. And finally, do you need it or do you want it? And I think you need to be honest and thoughtful as you're thinking about buying a new piece of equipment about whether you really need it or want it. And also to really pay attention about whether you're focusing in on the honest weak links in your production system or whether you're kind of defaulting to a, well, I need to buy something in order to cure, in order to make things better on my farm. There's a, sometimes there's a rush to cure. You know, if you're not happy with your farm, you're not happy with the quality of life of the economics, well, I'll just go out and buy something. I'll buy myself a new tractor and make my life better. And that's a dangerous treadmill to find yourself on. So here's another question for you all the way in on. Let's say we're a new grower and we're just starting out. We've got an acre and perhaps less than vegetables and we've got limited capitalization funds and we need, we feel like we just need so many different things to honor our farm. And here's four. We need a greenhouse. We feel like we need a tractor. We need a cold storage unit and we need a way to get our produce to market. Where should, how should we prioritize amongst these four big needs as we're just starting our farm? So can we set up a, can we set up a poll? We sure can set up a poll. So we, I'm going to polling type ABCD and people will give folks about a minute to choose one and then we'll publish it. So which one? ABC or D? Give folks about five more seconds and then we'll publish it. Once it's published it doesn't add your responses and that's why I wait. Okay, here we go. Publishing responses. Here we go. Okay, interesting. Well, you guys fell for my trap. This is my, anyway, my bias in talking with a lot of vegetable growers over the years, the thing that I think growers should buy first is the cold storage unit. And that's because on a vegetable farm you're dealing with perishable product. And fresh picked or picked just this morning is really not, really doesn't cut it on a fresh market vegetable farm. And let me just run down some of these other things. A greenhouse. You can actually get started on a very small scale growing plants inside or an even better option is to contract with a nearby farm and have them grow your transplants for you. You can get a lot done with a rototeller in the beginning years or if you really need to do tractor work you can have someone do that for you. And I found, I grow an acre or two of vegetables and I've actually been able to do quite a bit of delivery in a Pontiac vibe. So a delivery vehicle, you can usually get a lot of with a vehicle you have on hand. But there's not many options in terms of being able to keep produce cold. What I did on my farm my very first year when I knew I didn't have cold storage is that my very first year I grew winter squash, onions, and potatoes which don't require cold storage. So there's some ways around that. But I personally believe that the cold storage unit is absolutely the most important and the most important thing to do with a cold storage unit is absolutely the most important piece of equipment on a fresh produce form. If you're going to be a mail carrier you've got to have a delivery vehicle. There's just some fundamental things. And I think in order to be effective and profitable vegetable grower you've got to be able to store your product and deliver it fresh and in high quality. So that's my bias. Other people might argue with me. If somebody is asking where the passenger seat is in my Pontiac Vibe. No, the passenger seat is in. I'm able to get an entire 5 foot 6 foot high pallet of produce into my Pontiac Vibe. So generally, target areas of mechanization are you mechanize those areas that are demanding the most labor and are the most physically demanding. And I've got a grower friend who says this is driving me nuts. I'm a very motivated for where and when you need to capitalize. So for the vegetable growers and I'm going to give Jennifer a chance to weigh in on this as well in here in a few slides. But I really like to emphasize for vegetable growers the back end of your farm. And I've already given away some of my thunder here in terms of that question before. But I break the vegetable farm down into the front, the middle, and the back. And the front end of the vegetable farm is where you're producing transplants, planting seeds. It's your tractor in terms of your horse power, what's driving your farm in terms of power. Those primary tillage tools. That's the front end of the farm. The middle of the farm is taking care of weeds, irrigating, doing insect and disease management. And this is where I fit in fertility and cover crop management as well as you could argue that that maybe is the front end of your farm as well. I put it in here. And the back end of your farm is harvest, post harvest, storage, market sales, and delivery. And I think it's important for farms to emphasize the back end of their farm in the beginning. John, I'm just going to interject here as we had said I would be a little bit of a time keeper here just letting you know we've got seven minutes. Okay, great. So, especially with our food safety regulations coming, I think we need to emphasize the back end of our farms. I tell this all the time that we can need to avoid the picnic table approach to washing and packing on our farms. It's just not advisable. We need to have a covered area with washable tables and sinks. So here's a better example. And then even better is enclosed and having some efficient tools like wash lines to wash vegetables. So switching to a livestock perspective, this is one of my best friends as an organic beef farmer here in Wisconsin. And I've already kind of gone over most of this in terms of the message. But with animal production, your outstanding cost is feed. And if you look at the feed cost, that's true. So I think that's a good point. And if you look at the feed cost, that's driven by land, the cost of fertility and the cost of the equipment to produce that feed. And we're looking at a very different picture in terms of income per acre. And so land becomes a huge factor in terms of raising animals. So these pinch points are land and equipment. If you've got lots of land, great. If you don't, long-term rental agreements are a great option in terms of being able to have the land needed to raise animals. In terms of equipment, custom operators, rather than owning. My friend is an economist, and he's run endless numbers on the cost of raising animals. And it almost always, a full cost analysis almost always show you that having that hay-making equipment doesn't pay. It pays to have a customer operator. So, I'm going to leave it there and I apologize to Jennifer for not giving her much time to weigh in. Hopefully we'll leave some time at the end for her to weigh in a little bit more. Labor, biggest factor on a fresh-market vegetable farm. And so you've got to, and I really like to think about maximizing the impact of labor rather than trying to cut labor costs. I think it's more effective and proactive to think about how to maximize the impact of your labor and the impact of your work cruise. Anybody have any idea how much, maybe we won't do the full poll on this to save time. But what percent of gross income on an annual basis goes to payroll on a vegetable farm? This may be the easiest question of the three that I asked. I don't have the answer here on the next slide, but it's typically in that 20 to 40 percent range. Quite often 25 to 30 percent of a farm's payroll or annual gross income goes to payroll. I really like to tell farms to develop, try to develop efficient systems on their farms before hiring workers. It's one thing to do something in an efficient manner yourself. It's another thing to step aside and pay someone else to do that job inefficiently. So it really pays to be organized and develop systems on your farm. It really pays to be careful about who you hire and develop set expectations, set work rates and target times for tasks. And getting back to that weed thing, don't expand your farm unless you can manage the weeds. Nothing slows down labor on a vegetable farm, especially in terms of harvest. Like having to look for the crop which your weeds are out of control. And finally I think it's really important to invest in tools and facilities to make that harvest and post harvest handling more efficient because harvest and post harvest is going to where the majority of the labor is going to be on a vegetable farm. And so if you can invest in tools and equipment to make that more efficient you're going to be ahead in the game. So again, maximize the impact of your hired labor. And finally, try to find that right scale. Again, visit other farms, set goals, keep records, use those records to evaluate your farm and make informed decisions. Don't be afraid to invest in your farm. Again, most, especially on a vegetable farm, most of the equipment is going to pay for itself in terms of making your farm more efficient, improving your quality of life. And don't be afraid to make changes. If something's not working, you can change it. Wholesale markets aren't being profitable compared to your direct markets. Drop the wholesale or vice versa. And that's a dynamic process. You need to constantly re-evaluate your goals, your challenges, and your strategy each year. And just real quick, this is what I call the reality curve. This is something I show the beginning growers that I work with and the growers schools that I enter that we often begin our farms with a phase of naive enthusiasm which carries us to a certain point and then unfortunately we usually hit something that I call the root awakening which plummets us to the pit of despair and then we can start to get on track and have that breakthrough. And the unfortunate reality on most farms is that this is not just a one-time reality curve. This happens on a yearly basis or a weekly basis or even multiple times on a daily basis on our farms. A few quotes to... I'm not going to spend time discussing these. This is more thought pieces for you all to carry forward. I'm going to go ahead and do a few of these. I'm going to go ahead and do a few of these thought pieces for you all to carry forward with moving forward. The one I want to highlight is this first one. And this is a quote from the Market Farming List Serve again that I started with. Grower believes that a profitable farm operates at about 75% of the capacity of their invested resources, their equipment, their hired labor and their land. Below that, and you're probably going to be pushing your resources too hard and you're going to lack some flexibility. A few ideas on some resources for you all moving forward. I'm not going to read through those. These are some of my favorite resources to think about tools and equipment. And we'll end there with... I appreciate your feedback and my contact information. Great. John, I really want to thank you, Jennifer. I want to thank you. And I also wanted to let folks know that these resources and other resources will soon be available on our Groundwork website, which is just about to come live. Beth has been working hard on that. And then just wanted to encourage everybody to please do fill out the post-session evaluation. We take your feedback, really take it into account and try to develop a good program for folks. So thank you so much, John. Thank you so much, Jennifer. Thank you, everybody. Oh, Beth said, what's coming up in March? We thank you. February 13th, we have Richard... Richard, we have Wiz coming up, right? Richard Wizwell, who is going to be doing our second mechanization webinar, really focusing on what equipment you might want to focus on and looking more closely at the specific types of equipment. Again, focusing largely on cultivation equipment, veggie production, but certainly with livestock information as well. David DeWell, we will... I'll send out everybody contact information for Jennifer. Make sure that we're using the contact information she wants us to use. Jennifer, you could put that in right...

segments.text: So, welcome everybody to session two of the UVM Extension New Farmer Project's Groundwork
Program, Linking Mechanization to Farm Business Planning.
Our presenters today are John Hendrickson and also Jennifer Phillips.
Both John and Jennifer can tell you a little bit about themselves.
I think they prefer to do a self-introduction.
But for now, I'll just mention that John is joining us from the University of Wisconsin
and Jennifer from New York's Hudson Valley.
So welcome to both of you and I will pass it over to John.
Hello everyone.
We're getting up to 36 degrees out here in Wisconsin today, which is just really exciting,
given the polar vortex conditions that we've had.
Thanks, Kristen, and it's a pleasure to talk to everyone today.
It's interesting.
I do a lot of speaking to groups and maybe it's just because I don't do webinars as much,
but I'm more nervous and anxious today than I am when I'm in front of a big group of people
and they're staring at me.
But I'm sure we'll get things going smoothly here.
So my name is John Hendrickson and as Kristen said, I work at the University of Wisconsin specifically.
I'm an educator and researcher at the Center for Integrated Agricultural Systems.
We are a sustainable agriculture research and education unit.
And actually we're celebrating our 25th anniversary this year.
And so that's really exciting.
I've been with the Center for actually most of those 25 years.
I'm getting to be an old fart around here.
My appointment at the University is a nine month academic year appointment, 75% time,
which leaves me a very small sliver of my life to try to run my own farm.
And so I'm an organic vegetable grower at Stone Circle Farm, which is about 30 miles away
from Madison, quite small scale because I can't do too much in the amount of time
that I have away from my university work.
We grow a lot of garlic, a lot of carrots and a lot of hot peppers and are moving
into doing year round sales through the winter time with some of our root crops.
And we sell mostly to restaurants.
And so that's just a little tiny bit about my farm.
I'd love to talk more about my farm but I don't get to do that today.
In terms of my university work, I do a lot of beginning grower training programs.
These feature two to three day intensive workshops.
We have one on vegetable production, our market growers workshop.
And actually a weekend after next we have a cut flower workshop that we run basically every other year.
And then I also coordinate a school for beginning apple growers as well.
And we're thinking about doing more schools moving forward because these are incredibly popular
and there's an incredible amount of demand for them.
Just quickly here I've got a sketch of some of the types of work that I engage in.
I do a lot of work on economics and record keeping and labor issues on farms and marketing.
And I've got scale in bold there because for me the scale issue is just really critical
to just about any topic related to the farming.
I'm going to pause there and allow Jennifer to introduce herself.
Thanks John. I'll be brief here.
So thanks for inviting me today.
I have been raising sheep and beef cattle here in the Hudson Valley for about ten years.
The scale of my farm is moderately small.
I raise about 50 years, sell about 100 lambs a year and I sold my beef herd last year.
And I also have the academic hat on like John.
I teach at the Center for Environmental Policy at Bard College.
We run a graduate program, master's program and environmental policy there.
And my focus at the center is on greenhouse gas emissions
and climate change interactions with agriculture.
So my contribution here today will just be to add a little bit now and then
with some perspective on the livestock angle.
So thanks John. Go right ahead.
Great. Thanks Jennifer.
We invited Jennifer to join me today because my work really focuses almost exclusively
on vegetable production.
And while some of the information and ideas that I'm going to be sharing today are generalizable,
I wanted to ensure that we had some perspectives and examples from the livestock side as well.
Just before I leave this slide, I'll just quickly mention this grower to grower report.
That's the picture there on this slide.
This is a report I did a number of years ago looking at economics at different scales of production
on vegetable farms and really kind of forms the foundation for a lot of the work that I've done
since we published that back in 2005.
If you're interested in that report, it's a free download from the Center for Integrated Ag Systems website.
Okay, so scale. I really think that this quote kind of sums it up for me
and this is a quote from the market farming listserv that I subscribe to.
And this is not a quote from me, but I think the whole thing comes down to this.
What is the right scale for my operation?
The challenge is to find a size that represents a good fit for a grower's management skills.
And of course, there's a whole set of issues that are wrapped up in that scale issue.
How much land you have available to you, what your quality of life goals are,
what your income needs are, and maybe just as big a factor as the scale of your operation
is your crop and market diversity.
This is especially true on diversified vegetable farms
where the level of diversity can be quite high and also the amount of marketing,
and the different types of marketing engaged in can be quite high as well.
And then that all, the big issues that that settles down to is how are you going to manage labor
and what types of tools and equipment are you going to use on your farm?
This is a rundown of the goals for today's session.
I know that you all received this set of goals, so I'm not going to go over these one by one.
You all received these as a prelude to today's session.
This is my goal for today is to run through most of these, or all of these in some level of detail.
Before we get started, I want to kind of put mechanization in context.
And a lot of this context, again, is going to be based on my experience as a vegetable grower
and working with vegetable growers.
Especially in the early years of a farm's development, mechanization is most often linked to expansion.
So a farm starts out real small, maybe with not a whole lot of tools and equipment.
And then as they get bigger, they find the need to acquire those tools and equipment
in order to get the work accomplished in a reasonable fashion.
So that expansion can be an acreage, it can be a herd size.
It can also be in terms of the different markets and enterprises that a farm may engage in
as they move forward with their farm operation.
At the same time, as we're trying to mechanize, we often have very little capitalization funds
to do that.
And there are a lot of growers who are quite adverse to debt and risk.
And so that limits their available capitalization funds even more because many people don't
like to rush out to the bank and put themselves in that debt situation.
But that situation that most growers do find themselves in, unless they've inherited
land or find themselves in an incubator situation or what have you, is land cost.
And this can really limit the amount of money that a grower has available to mechanize.
And so what that usually does is puts them on kind of a long, slow process of mechanization
over time.
There are very few growers that can kind of run out and buy that equipment package that
they dream about all at once.
Oh, if we could do that.
This is really obvious, but mechanization is very closely linked to labor.
This is especially true on a diversified vegetable farm where there's just a lot of hand work.
And a lot of that hand work takes a lot of time.
And so payroll becomes a real significant issue.
And in some regards, mechanization is an attempt to try to hone in that labor cost
or at least make it more effective and more productive.
And to recognize that mechanization purchases are not just about getting some work done,
but they're really investments in your business.
And they have a significant impact on a business's financial picture in terms of your net worth
and your annual budget picture, financial picture for your farm.
Another reality is that it is quite common for investments, decisions to be made with very little
financial analysis, and this can certainly lead to problems.
On real large scale farms, it can lead pretty quickly to real significant debt
and really nasty situations between your banker.
But a lot of small farms can kind of keep us at bay because generally the equipment needed
is not generally as expensive as a large scale grain farm.
I know a lot of farms that just kind of jump in and get started without a business plan.
I'm a firm believer that at least a simple basic business plan is a really important step to take.
And an important section in a business plan should be your start-up expenses and capitalization.
So what tools are you going to need to run this business?
What are those going to cost? And how are you going to pay for those?
In order to estimate your needs and expenses accurately, I think it's really, really important
to visit other farms, attend conferences and trade shows.
And of course these days so much information is available online and so you have the ubiquitous
command to just Google it and find out.
It is actually a great research tool, the Internet.
In addition to figuring out deciding what kinds of equipment and tools you need,
you need to figure out how you're going to pay for those.
Savings, family contributions, where they're going to go get a loan.
And in many cases what's involved is reinvestment.
Those first few years, if you're able to make some money, you're usually plowing that money
right back into the farm in terms of capitalizing and mechanizing.
So this is something that I recommend that all farms start with.
This is basically an example of what you might include in your business plan in terms of that
start-up expenses and capitalization.
You list the items that you're going to need.
I think it's nice to have two columns in terms of cost.
What's it going to cost new, you know, top of the line or maybe a lower cost alternative
or used.
And then also to include a cost to rent or hire, which is an option,
especially as you get started.
And then you might have a column out to decide to make some notes
or to give different types of tools and equipment a priority ranking
as you move forward.
One thing that I think is really helpful is to set up categories,
which can help you plan more accurately and systematically.
So for your farm, you can set up categories of things,
categories of tools and equipment that you're going to need so you can make sure
that you're covering all your bases.
For a vegetable farm, this might be a power source, you know,
your tractor or if you're farming with horses, it could be horses.
The tools that are going to be attached to that power source,
and then you can break those down into different types of tools,
tillage, cultivation, harvest, et cetera.
And then it's really important to consider the post-harvest and delivery aspects
as well on a vegetable farm.
And those categories are going to be different based on the type of farm,
the farm that you're going to have for a livestock farm.
You might have different categories.
Obviously manure handling, you might be doing that on your vegetable farm,
but for an animal farm, you're definitely going to be doing that.
And then you're going to be looking to make hay
and transporting animals around so that the categories might be different.
So just a quick check-in to make sure that you all are paying attention
and following along. This is one of these multiple choice questions
that we are going to ask you to weigh in on and ask you,
what do you think it costs on a per acre basis to capitalize a vegetable farm
in terms of equipment?
And, Kristyn, if you want to jump in here and you probably can tell people
how to choose multiple choice questions faster than I do.
Sure. So what I'm going to do is actually make the polls,
the polling type. How many choices do we need, John?
Four? Five. All right. So thank you for your patience.
So now you can go up to the polling box to the right of the smiley face icon
and choose your answer, A, B, C, D, or E.
And we'll give folks about a minute and then I'll hit publish poll
and then we'll all be able to see what the answers were.
And John, I'm not sure if you see Kristyn's question where she says,
wouldn't five be different per acre than 15 with the average cost per acre decreasing?
As you're answering that, I'll hit publish poll.
Sure. Sure. Yeah, this is a general question
and things can certainly vary on a per acre basis.
I've actually collected information on this.
Some of it is contained in that Grower to Grower report that I found.
And I actually found, well, there's certainly a great deal of variation
from scale to scale of farm that you look at a collection of farms
and you look at enough farms and you actually find that it actually can be relatively even
across farms of different scales. So we've got some people that didn't vote,
but we have people coming in actually pretty evenly distributed across B, C, and D.
And I'm going to go to my next slide here and based on the information that I've gathered from farms,
I've seen things in the range from $10,000 to $20,000 per acre.
And so I kind of use that as a general rule of thumb in terms of capitalization.
And one thing to say here is it certainly is going to vary whether we're talking about the initial price
of the equipment or after you've got that on your farm, what the resale value is going to be for that equipment.
And also, obviously, it's going to be impacted by whether we're going to include facilities.
For this exercise, I chose to exclude facilities.
But I really have seen that even for small farms, two, three acres,
this can be the case where growers are investing $10,000 to $20,000 per acre in order to grow vegetables.
I'm going to ask Jennifer to chime in here in terms of livestock here in a second.
But before we leave this slide, just to give you a snapshot of things that we might be looking at
in terms of capitalizing a fresh market vegetable farm, we're going to need a set of facilities.
We're likely going to need a greenhouse to grow transplants, perhaps as a place to grow crops as well
in terms of hoop house production. You're going to need a place to wash and pack.
And you're going to need a cooler.
And then in terms of equipment, this is just a real brief sketch of some things that might be an initial
priority equipment list for a vegetable farm.
There's a question here in terms of whether that's $10,000 to $20,000 invested annually.
Now, this is your equipment package that you have on your farm spread over your acreage and vegetables.
If anybody has a question that I miss in the chat box, please alert me to that because I'm not looking at the chat box vigorously here.
Jennifer, do you want to chime in here and switch to the next slide here?
And have you weigh in on what it might cost to capitalize a livestock operation?
Sure. It's a little bit different.
I think it depends so much on how many animals you're starting with because there's a lot you can get away with
when you've only got a few animals to begin.
The two main things that I found I had to have under my own control were ability to brush hog my pastures
because in most cases you're starting out with pastures that aren't in the kind of condition you need them to be in,
especially if you're grass-fed, you need pretty high quality pasture.
And once you have a whole lot of animals to begin with,
and you can do some serious mob grazing where you're really concentrating animals,
you really need to mow a lot in order to get your quality up.
So I think you need some kind of a tractor to begin with.
And then the other part of the season that you need to think about with a tractor is that unless you've got less than, say,
15 sheep or a couple of cows, you really need to be using round bales for winter feed as opposed to small square bales.
And so you need to be able to move them. And so you have to have a tractor for that.
I know of a few small-scale sheep farmers around here that tried to start their operation without a tractor,
and it didn't work for who-how.
But most, you listed a set of issues that a livestock farmer may face right in the beginning,
and that's handling manure, haymaking, and transport.
And I think it will depend a lot on your situation whether or not you might be able to be feeding,
doing winter feeding on pasture so you really don't have a lot of manure handling to deal with.
I actually-I use a winter area, but my vegetable farmer neighbor across the road,
he transports all my manure and spreads some of it for me and spreads the rest on his own fields every year.
So I don't need any manure handling equipment.
And haymaking, I think, until you get to a pretty sizable operation, in my perspective,
it does not make sense to make your own hay and have hay making equipment.
I purchased hay for the first nine years of my operation, and this past year was the first year I had hay made by somebody custom on my farm.
And the advantage there is, of course, you don't have to deal with the labor of it.
And the hay that I was purchasing was better quality than I was able to have made on this farm
because when you're hiring custom operators, of course, you're competing with everybody else they're trying to make hay for,
so you don't necessarily get it done when you want.
But purchasing hay, that hay had been stored indoors from a large-scale hay producer.
So it's-and he was delivering-you know, he would deliver to me once a week so I could store it inside my barn when he delivered round bales.
So it's much better quality than what I could have done on my own farm.
It costs more, but it's also a lot of labor that I don't have to put out if I'm purchasing all my hay or having somebody make it custom on my farm.
And then transport, one of the big advantages of-I don't have a truck, I don't have a stock trailer,
